qas.question: Which idea is the controversy of affirmative action primarily based upon?
Other than African Americans, who do detractors of affirmative action claim benefit most from affirmative action?
At who's expense other than Asian Americans are upper-class African Americans and Hispanic Americans supposedly benefiting?
What do some people believe should be the basis for affirmative action instead of race based legislation?
Who primarily makes up America's poor group?
Which idea is the controversy of non-affirmative action primarily based upon?
Other than Asian Americans, who do detractors of affirmative action claim benefit most from affirmative action?
At whose expense other than African Americans are upper-class African Americans and Hispanic Americans supposedly benefiting?
What do some people believe should be the basis for affirmative action instead of religion based legislation?
Who primarily makes up America's rich group?

context: The controversy surrounding affirmative action's effectiveness is based on the idea of <a0_0><b5_0>class inequality<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Opponents of racial affirmative action argue that the program actually benefits middle- and upper-class African Americans and <a1_0><b6_0>Hispanic<b6_0/> Americans<a1_0/> at the expense of <a2_0><b7_0>lower-class European Americans<b7_0/><a2_0/> and Asian Americans. This argument supports the idea of class-based affirmative action. America's poor is disproportionately made up of <a4_0>people of color<a4_0/>, so <a3_0><b8_0>class-based affirmative action<b8_0/><a3_0/> would disproportionately help people of color. This would eliminate the need for race-based affirmative action as well as reducing any disproportionate benefits for middle- and upper-class <b9_0>people of color<b9_0/>.
